dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying.  Not at the intangible height of a jet, but at spitting distance from the treetops.  We're in central Alaska, the Big Lonely, just north of the Arctic Circle. A thick forest follows the contours of mountain foothills like a deep-pile carpet.  Up at treeline the forest thins tundra, a grassy scruff turning red and yellow with the coming of autumn. On the horizon, the hills rise to meet the Endicott Mountains, a great fortress wall of granite so sharp and jagged that snow cannot stick to its face.  This is how a North America once looked -- raw, indomitable. Then, abruptly coming into the SCENE is a colossal etchin across the landscape too deliberate to be of natural orig Bisecting this country like a metallic ribbon -- or a sca depending on your point of view -- is the 800-mile-long Trans-Alaskan Pipeline. Even the immensity of the pipeline is rendered insignific by the vastness of the land.  It goes on, and on, and on.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: A lone MAN walks along the Haul Road, a one-lane gravel trail running parallel to the pipeline.  The weather turn sour -- rough wind and stinging snow cut across the man's path.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: The man is ERIC DESMOND, twenty-four, clean-shaven, determined.  He's clearly out of place here, dressed in a business suit and a light, camel-hair topcoat. Eric is trying to follow some footprints in the snow -- a predator's tracks, those of a wolf or coyote.  But the footprints ahead have faded, covered by the snow and wind

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: The weather becomes more oppressive.  Heavy snow, gale wi and sub-zero temperatures make his progress tortuous.  Er strives stubbornly forward.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Eric has gathered some branches.  He tries to make a fire Moisture from his breath has frozen in the upturned colla of his insufficient coat, and his skin is split raw from cold. His hands are too numb to hold the matches.  After severa attempts at striking one, he slumps down next to the pile wood, exhausted and frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: The snow has covered the pile of branches.  Eric still si next to it, partially covered in snow himself.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: His face is a death mask: eyes half-open and dull, lips a purplish blue, bloodless skin crystallizing as it ices ov The wind HOWLS around him.  The snow sticks to his eyelas and hair without melting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric bolts up in bed.  Next to him, ANNE MARIE GAUVIN sit up and hugs him.  All that can be seen of her in the dark a lovely silhouette and a cascade of dark hair.  After a moment, Eric kisses her.  He shakes off the dream and lie back down.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A metal sign, peppered with shotgun holes, is posted near pipeline support piling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric walks quietly past the sign, intent on something ahe of him.  Although still somewhat boyish in appearance, he confident and resolute in attitude.  His clothes have a distinctly western feel: Lucchese boots, Levis 501's, Mah cotton shirt.  His down parka is unzipped in the sunny, windless, forty-degree afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He pauses, then brings to his shoulder a rifle with a four-power scope mounted atop it.  He peers through the scope.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH SCOPE
dialogues.text: He puts the crosshairs on the shoulder flank of a big, ivory-white timber wolf, fifty yards away.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Anne Marie stands beside Eric, a Nikon with a telephoto l in her hand, holding her breath in anticipation.  She's twenty-three, pretty, with soft features and piercing blu eyes.  She wears Eddie Bauer woman's gear like she was bo in it. Eric expertly fixes his aim and slowly squeezes the trigg But instead of a loud retort, there is only the dull POP a CO2-powered dart gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tranquilizer dart finds its mark in the wolf's fleshy shoulder.  The wolf takes off running, but almost immediately slows, sits, then lies down. Eric and Anne Marie hurry over to the wolf, who is breath deeply.  Eric kneels next to him and strokes his thick fu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beauty. (to Anne Marie) Hand me the transmitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie passes to Eric a tiny, weatherproof homing dev attached to a steel collar band.  Eric puts the collar loosely around the wolf's neck and crimps it in place, al the while TALKING soothingly to the semi-conscious animal Anne Marie smiles at Eric's tenderness and snaps some photos. With the collar in place and transmitter activated, Eric backs away while the wolf tries to rouse itself from its narcosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) He's coming around fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right back.  I left my camcorder in the car.

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW ANNE MARIE
dialogues.text: as she hurries back to their International Scout.  On the door of the Scout is a stylized logo of an oil derrick, under which are the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NORTHLAND PETROLEUM CORP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie opens the hatchback and grabs a video camera.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC AND THE WOLF
dialogues.text: Eric smiles as the wolf wobbles tentatively to his feet a trots unsteadily away.  Near the treeline the wolf turns, glances back at Eric and then disappears into the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie is taping the wolf's retreat.  Looking through the viewfinder, she crosses a gully between a pipeline piling and a rock formation.  Eric turns toward her and a glint of light in the debris at her feet catches his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie!  Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances down.  Something metal is half-buried in the dead leaves and gravel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric runs over.  He pokes at the object with a stick.  Wi a SNAP, a steel leg trap chomps the stick in half.  Anne Marie jumps back.  Eric brushes the dead leaves on the ground behind her and she carefully backtracks out of the gully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Goddamn trappers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He angrily rips the trap out of the ground, unearthing several others attached to one another by a long chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Takes nerve, laying traplines on restricted land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric slips the scope off the dart rifle and climbs up the pipeline on foot pegs to the top of an anchoring poINT.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Using the scope as a telescope, he scans up and down the Haul Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still might be around.  I saw fresh tire tracks coming in.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH SCOPE
dialogues.text: The road and the pipeline stretch toward either horizon, north and south.  In the distance, a jeep is parked on th Haul Road.  Near it, a Man climbs down into another shall ravine.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Eric hurries down the footpegs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man and a jeep, about a mile and a half down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps into the Scout.  Anne Marie stuffs her cameras i the hatchback.  As soon as she climbs in, Eric tears out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It races along the dusty gravel road at 60 MPH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled at the APPROACH of the Scout, the Trapper uproot his traps and runs out of the ravine.  He WHISTLES and another Trapper appears nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pile into their dilapidated, all-terrain jeep.  It's oddly well-equipped, however.  Bolted to the dashboard is expensive tape player and a beat-up radio beacon receiver with a round locating screen.  They zoom off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric stomps on the gas.  The dust from the jeep obscures view but he's gaining on them anyway.  Anne Marie hangs o and squints her eyes against the choking dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver is LEMALLE (35), a tall, ugly, rawboned Canadi His entire outfit is made of animal hide.  He has long re hair, and a reptilian face usually twisted into a sadisti sneer.  While driving, he scans along the pipeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the fuck did you drop Corbett off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the passenger seat, MITCHELL (38), chews tobacco and looks grim.  He's a squat, flat-faced Okie, with curly matted hair and tired grey eyes.  He's dressed in a brown long coat and has a Colt .45 Peacemaker in a quick-draw holster strapped to his leg.  Despite his intimidating ai confrontation is not his style. He spots a figure up ahead, where the road crosses a mudd creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning sharply, the trappers' jeep splashes through the creek bed without slowing.  Bouncing, it comes down hard against the axle-deep bank at the creek's high water mark LeMalle tries to back out, but can't find traction in the mud. Eric stops the Scout thirty yards behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric opens his door.  To Anne Marie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful -- there're two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric reaches in the back seat and hands something to Anne Marie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I unzip my parka, stick this out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric confidently approaches the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then, a third trapper climbs from the creek.  He's got a line of traps slung around his neck and a world of experience on his face.  He's BEN CORBETT, a life-long huntsman, somewhere past forty, weathered beyond his year He has a feral nose, thick beard and dark, smart, hunter' eyes.  He wears a hooded cotton sweat shirt, cotton coveralls and vapor-barrier mountain boots.  On his belt a holster rig cradling a .44 magnum revolver. Eric slows down.  He didn't expect to face anyone as formidable as Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emboldened by Corbett's presence, LeMalle reaches into th back seat and grabs his 6.5 by 55 Swedish military carbin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to LeMalle) No shooting.  Let's see who's so interested in us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett has an incongruously affable voice.  He throws hi traps into the jeep, then strides closer toward Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Corbett) Ain't worth it, Ben...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Corbett comes closer, Eric realizes this might not've been a great idea.  Corbett squints his eyes and sniffs t air, as if by this he can gauge his opponent's mettle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got two counts against you -- trapping out of season and poaching on restricted land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be much of a crime, if all they got minding the area is a cocky kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got your plate number, asshole. Maybe you feel like spending a few months in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But LeMalle, rankled, sticks the carbine out the jeep window. Seeing the rifle pointed at him, Eric freezes, then slowl unzips his parka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben?  Sure you don't want me to drop the fucker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett doesn't answer.  Then, his eyes narrow and he loo past Eric at the Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passenger in the Scout sticks what looks like another rifle out the window.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Eric quickly glances over his shoulder to make sure Anne Marie's backing him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave and don't come back, that's the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a long moment, Corbett smiles again, then turns awa from Eric.  He motions LeMalle to the front of the jeep. Frustrated, LeMalle slams back the safety on the carbine throws it in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPERS
dialogues.text: Mitchell climbs into the jeep and starts the engine. LeMalle and Corbett rock the jeep back and forth in the r While pushing, Corbett rips the sole of his boot on a sha piece of granite.   He cusses and pushes harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric walks back to the Scout.  He feels the trappers' eye on his back, but forces himself not to hurry. The trappers free their vehicle.  Corbett gets in the driver's seat, and they take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie's hands are shaking as she pulls the plastic tranquilizer rifle back in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unnerved) Great idea -- pointing a lousy dart gun at some nut with a high-powered hunting rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastards took off, though, didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers have left the flatlands of the Haul Road are Now their jeep climbs a pathway over the rolling foothill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett broods while driving.  Mitchell looks out the window.  The silence makes LeMalle uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this fuckin' land, and we're locked out.  Makes me puke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jawing about it won't change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hundred seventy-five million acres in this state.  I'm real tired of runnin' into people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't look to your left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brand-new Land Rover is parked on an alluvial fan in a bend in a small river.  Scattered about is an assortment expensive camping gear, beer cans, spent shells and other garbage. Three toy-macho, vacationing SPORTSMEN are guzzling beer BLASTING fish in the shallow river with 12-gauge shotguns They look up and glower suspiciously as the jeep slows an stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle grabs his carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's keep going.  We're only an hour from Devil's Cauldron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pats Mitchell's shoulder) Relax.  I just want to ask them how the hunting is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett gets out of the jeep.  He regards the Sportsmen, their shotguns and their mess with ill-concealed contempt The Sportsmen clutch their weapons and watch Corbett.  He walks around the camp, spotting a rubber-lined rucksack stuffed with dead ermine.  After a long, tense moment, Corbett smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you've had some luck. Where's your guide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on our own, if it's any of your damn business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re ermine) You did real good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crouches next to the dead animals and strokes the fur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Corbett) No swinging shit.  They're over their goddamned limit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sportsmen) My friend is right.  Supposed to have a licensed guide when you're on this land, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we paid our fuckin' permit fees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle amuses himself by pissing in their campfire.  No notices that in the b.g., quiet Sportsman #3 unzips his parka, exposing a .45 Peacemaker in a belt holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I were you, I'd drive right on outta here again.  Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) This was my roaming land, 'til the government took it over. Only Innuit can hunt here now, and tourists, like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett swings the rucksack of carcasses onto the hood of the Land Rover.  Pissed, Sportsmen #1 and #2 step closer him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) According to tribal law, hunters passing through the land of another tribe can only take game to survive.  They can eat the meat, but have to surrender the hides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle pulls a hunting knife and holds up one of the ermine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want the meat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, dirtball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett chuckles and Mitchell spits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle digs through the camping goodies in the back of t Land Rover, many still in their packages.  He helps himse to some sandwiches and a 12-pack of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say shoot 'em, bury 'em with their shiny new car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to LeMalle) If you're gonna take something, take it and let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett looks down to fasten the top of the rucksack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Sportsman #3 reaches inside his parka and pulls the pistol.  He swings it toward LeMalle. LeMalle looks up when he hears the HAMMER cock. There is a deafeningly loud SHOT. Sportsman #3 falls down dead at LeMalle's feet. Off to one side, Corbett holds a huge, smoking .44 magnum six-shooter in his hand. Shotgun in hand, Sportsman #1 gauges his chances of blast Corbett.  Nil.  When Corbett turns to him, he lies the weapon down.  Sportsman #2 rushes to his friend. Looking bleak, Mitchell spits again.  Corbett crosses to LeMalle and knocks from his hands the things he wanted to steal.  Chastised, LeMalle smolders.  After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sportsmen) Put him in your truck.  Smell of blood will attract the bears. (to trappers) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Corbett walks to the jeep, he's too angry to notice th he's stepped in a patch of mud under the Land Rover. Near the jeep, LeMalle stops and pulls them into a huddle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe in leavin' witnesses behind, Ben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was self defense.  Leave it at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think those fucks will tell it that way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ending the argument) We'll get a head start before they go crying to the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett turns and FIRES two rounds from his .44 into the engine of the Land Rover.  The Sportsmen stare and sputte

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Sportsmen) You can pack out of here -- two, three days' hike along this river at most.  Weather should hold this early in the season.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett and Mitchell get in their jeep.

dialogues.speaker: LEMALLE
dialogues.text: isn't yet satisfied.  He walks back over to the Sportsmen kneeling beside their fallen friend, and crouches right beside them.  Intimidated, Sportsman #2 looks away, but LeMalle grabs his chin and turns his face back toward him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I'm pretty?  You better forget how we look, 'cause next time they won't keep me from killing you.  This land ain't quite civilized, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unsheathes his buck knife.  BELOW FRAME, he slices acr the forehead of the dead Sportsman, peels back his scalp cuts it loose, Indian-style.  The Sportsmen are stunned a sickened.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPERS' JEEP
dialogues.text: Corbett looks at Mitchell and wearily shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least he scalped the dead one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devil's Cauldron Hot Springs is a cluster of twenty tiny dwellings connected by an unpainted boardwalk.  The town squats, ugly and temporary-looking, in a dirt clearing fi miles north of the Arctic Circle.  Thirty miles east of t Pipeline, it's almost dead center of interior Alaska. At the edge of town is a gravel airstrip.  Mixed with the prospector-era sod-roof cabins are a few prefabricated houses.  The boon brought by men building the pipeline is long gone.  Now only a few itinerant loggers, natives and bush dwellers remain to fight boredom, each other and the depression of the oncoming winter. Enough steam escapes from the hot springs to perpetually blanket the valley with fog.  The spa is log-walled and horseshoe- shaped, with partitioned baths inside.  Facing

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: are a mud-walled fire bath, a wooden steam bath called a Maqi, six one-room cabins for let, and an unused dance ha LEO MEYERLING opens the tailgate of a Dodge truck with th Northland Petroleum logo and "District Supervisor" on the door.  Meyerling is short and bald with a completely disreputable face.  He staples a poster on a wall.  It ha picture of him on it, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: for State Legislature VOTE FOR THE PEOPLE'S FRIEND!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett and the other trappers drive past Meyerling and p their jeep as the sun disappears behind the foothills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handwritten public notice next to a schedule of church meetings reads: "Live each day so you can look every damn man in the eye and tell him to go to hell."  There is a p office in the corner with some combination boxes and a wicketless window. The trappers come in.  Corbett sits in a chair and pulls boots off.  One of his wool socks is wet.  He nods to the man sitting in the other chair, SAM WILDER.  Wilder is sh and tough, with a full head of crewcut grey hair and weather- ravaged face that makes him look older than his sixty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hullo, Sam.  Slow day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary) Ben...boys.  Yeah, real slow, and I'd like to keep it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) Just passing through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chubby Inupiat (interior Eskimo), wearing thick glasses several heavy sweaters and battery-heated socks, fusses behind the counter.  He's EARL KENAI, owner of the hot springs spa and the general store. LeMalle chews on a handful of bear jerky.  Kenai stares a LeMalle until he begrudgingly pays for the jerky.  Corbet pulls on some sneakers and hands his boots to Kenai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; re boot) Needs patching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Sure have learned to worship the white man's god.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenai nods agreeably and holds his hand out.  Corbett pay him.  Meyerling comes in and posts some fliers on the corkboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I can count on you gentlemen to vote for The People's Friend this November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Share some of that oil company money in your pocket and you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meyerling smiles like a toad, then slaps another poster o the wall.  LeMalle throws his knife and it STICKS in the poster between Meyerling's spread fingers.  Meyerling jum back and the trappers laugh.  Meyerling looks to Wilder f support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Meyerling) One flier comes loose and I shoot you for littering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exiting; grudgeless) Have your fun... just remember The People's Friend come election day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Oil Company candidate running on that slogan makes about as much sense as a rat fucking a grapefruit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to work up an interest in politics, way we live.  You're the first people we've seen in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kenai) How about a quart of Jack Daniel's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it is right.  Back in the primary this town was voted dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Corbett) Aw, shit.  Let's go.  Leave a note for Viking Bob, tell him to meet us in Cache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  One more day without drink won't kill you.  Right, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm living proof of that sad fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we buy the Marshal some dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I better stay at my post. Even without the hootch riling 'em up, you know how mean-spirited folks get when they smell winter coming.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: An early STORM has blown in from the north, bringing whipping winds and freezing rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett peers out the tiny window, frowning.  LeMalle cle his carbine while eating beans and bacon.  Mitchell hunch over a table.  He's making a scrimshaw -- delicately engraving, using homemade tools, on a palm-sized piece of whale bone.  He rubs his eyes and looks up at Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much for the walking weather you predicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had no choice... (pointedly, at LeMalle) ...Given the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Least you didn't shoot all of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mitchell.  Woulda been my ass if Ben didn't waste that prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Mitchell, look, it don't take three of us to wait for Viking Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell glances at LeMalle, then at Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Go ahead.  Take the jeep.  I'll come to Cache with Bob when he gets here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay by me.  You're the one likes these hot springs so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave my traps.  We'll tag up, couple days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The winds have died down.  The rain has turned to a light snow. A mobile arctic dwelling sits on a rise next to the Haul Road.  It's a double-unit weathertight cocoon of fibergla and aluminum, pulled by a diesel rig on oversized tires. The front module is 12 by 24, the rear 12 by 18. An extended-cab pickup pulls up and Sam Wilder gets out. The gravel-and-dirt Haul Road, paralleling the pipeline f 400 miles, is closed to the public.  An arriving vehicle, therefore, is news.  The front door of the dwelling opens Eric and Anne Marie come outside, delighted to see Wilder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was making my rounds, saw your hangar wide open, plane getting rained on, so I closed it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wilder) I bet you haven't had lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Bet you're right.  But I didn't come by to wangle a meal --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We appreciate the company. Anne Marie's getting cabin fever already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie shoots a look at Eric but doesn't disagree -- this is obviously an issue with them.  Wilder looks with amusement at the mobile dwelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say they call these spaceships?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mobile Arctic Dwelling -- MAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call it 'the Turtle,' as in carrying your home on your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best thing is, Meyerling has to chase around to find us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) The little creep hates it that Eric actually does what the company hired him to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it with Meyerling.  Man's as mean and corrupt as they get. Cut his mother's throat if it'd get him a couple votes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Looking past Wilder, Eric points out some smoke on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sam, look over there.  Black and white smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.  Likely that's an SOS. Have to pass on that lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything seems peaceful enough.  The SOS fire (made fro burning green branches for white smoke and rubber for bla smoke) has burnt down to embers. Eric, Anne Marie and Wilder pull up in Wilder's pickup. The two Sportsmen sit in the front seat of the Land Rover but they don't react to the arrival of the rescuers.  In back seat, a reflective camping blanket covers a large ma Something is amiss.  Eric shoots a look of trepidation at Anne Marie as they get out of the pickup.   Wilder pulls door of the Land Rover open. A Sportsman slumps out onto the ground.  His eyes are ope and his tongue pokes out between his lips.  His skin is blue-white. (He looks, in fact, much like Eric's nightmar Startled, Eric steps back.  Anne Marie gasps with horror. Wilder unzips the Sportsman's light windbreaker and liste for a heartbeat.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid goddamn greenhorns!  Froze to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even winter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got wet in the rain.  Core body temperature dropped, got drowsy, probably didn't even know what was happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric stares at the dead Sportsmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Question is why they sat here when the storm moved in.  Check their stuff while I sniff around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder tries the ignition.  The starter TURNS OVER, but t engine makes a horrendous GRINDING.  He walks to the fron of the vehicle.  Noticing the bullet holes in the grille, bends down for a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric opens the rear hatchback and digs through the plenti supplies.  Still in their packages are some matchbox-size ELT locating beacons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had Emergency Locater Transmitters, but didn't use them. (opens one up; shakes his head) Maybe because they didn't bring batteries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie opens the back door of the Land Rover.  She pu back the camping blanket... and uncovers the third Sportsman.  The torn red flesh on his head and his bugged-out eyes are a hideous sight. Anne Marie SCREAMS and stumbles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric runs over to her as she tries to catch her breath. Wilder looks at the third Sportsman and angrily kicks the side of the Land Rover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea who could've done it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sourly, Wilder points to a patch of frozen mud under the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A certain sonofabitch bastard -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILDER (Cont'd) wearing a damaged mountain boot. Left a footprint clear as an autograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder examines the Sportsman, finding the bullet hole in his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Even for Ben Corbett, this is nasty.  Man's got balls.  He was sitting in Devil's Cauldron when I left, calm as can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.  You can arrest him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily.  Corbett's awful hardbitten these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder leans against the Land Rover, feeling tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) His old roaming area's all private reserve now.  Normally, long as he stays civil in my jurisdiction, I let him be. (beat) Won't be able to take him by my lonesome, though.  Nobody in town'll lift a finger on this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric looks hard at the dead Sportsmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'll go into town with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric, leave it alone.  It's not your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) No way can he get away with this. I'll be back by tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town is quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett soaks in one of the huge wooden tubs with a pudgy Inupiat hooker, DIXIE. He looks up as Eric comes into the spa.  Eric holds Corbett's boots, which have been repaired.  Eric pauses w he sees Corbett.  There is a flash of recognition between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Corbett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.  Afraid you have me at a disadvantage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenai at the general store asked me to bring these.  Didn't expect we'd already met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No big deal.  We just got off on the wrong foot.  What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric glances down at Corbett's duffel bag, which sits on floor next to Corbett's tub.  Corbett's magnum rests on t of it, well within reach.  Corbett notices Eric's interes in it.  He leans back and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Desmond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New to the country, kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months.  Ecological study for Northland Oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecology.  Folks use that term for everything but what it means: who's eating who.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Putting his hand on Dixie's shoulder, Corbett stands and gets out of the tub.  His sinewy body, resembling a scarecrow made of steel cable, is covered with scars.  He wraps a towel around his waist and crosses to Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Now, why don't you get around to saying what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett grabs his boots from Eric and finds himself facin revolver, which Eric has been hiding inside one of the boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; smiling) You wouldn't shoot anyone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder has come in the back way and stands behind Corbett with a 12-gauge shotgun.  He kicks Corbett's magnum out o reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this for laying traps on private land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left a footprint at the Sportsmen's camp.  Only pretty sight there, Ben, 'cause the two men you didn't shoot and mutilate died of exposure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett shakes his head but remains implacable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ if I shouldn't know better than to step in soft earth.  I've seen footprints in the tundra a hundred years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eric) I got it from here.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wilder) Sam, give Dixie here fifty bucks out of my kit, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric comes outside.  Earl Kenai, overdressed for the weat in gloves, mukluks and a full-length sealskin coat, stand

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: shivering by a woodshed near the hot springs, hacksawing piece of meat from a frozen moose carcass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before white men came, my people lived in sod houses underground and laid our dead on the tundra. Now we live above ground and bury our dead, and we haven't been warm since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder comes out of the spa with his shotgun and Corbett' duffel bag cradled in his arm.  Handcuffed, Corbett walks front of him. Kenai looks down to avoid eye contact with Corbett as he goes by.  Corbett stops next to Eric and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice bluff the other day with the tranquilizer gun out your jeep window.  See you again, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unintimidated) Yeah.  Maybe so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he leads Corbett along the boardwalk to the other end town.  They approach a prefab house perched on skids unde tall antenna tower.  Mounted above the shack, a DC wind charger turbine spins lazily in the faint breeze.  From within the cabin comes an anomalous SOUND -- MTV.  Wilder KNOCKS on the door. ARTHUR NEFF, a pasty-white, 45-year-old ex-Texan, pulls t door open.  His customary grin fades when he sees Corbett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder pushes Corbett inside past Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to call Fairbanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff just stares at Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Neff!  Dial it up.  State police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a "what can I do but oblige?" look to Corbett, Neff sits in front of the RCA Alascom radio telephone and dial

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Fairbanks Alascom?  Patch me through to the State Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, he hands the receiver to Wilder.  Wilder takes it, keeping one eye and the shotgun on Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) This is Sam Wilder, Marshal in Devil's Cauldron.  Had some killings here.  I got a suspect; be real nice if someone came and took him off my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thru phone) On a good day I couldn't spare a crosswalk guard.  But now, no way.  Folks're batshit with the weather turning sour.  Bring him in yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Next plane's not coming 'til next Monday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thru phone) Sit your suspect out in the cold. He'll keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) This man's friends ain't gonna look favorably on his incarceration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thru phone; Mr. Glib) So shoot him.  Won't have to feed him that way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angry, Wilder slams the receiver down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one room, there is a wood-burning cookstove and an Ash heat stove, a table, a bunk and a small window.  Behind a cloth partition is an eight by six holding cell.  The fra of an iron-bar door is securely cemented to the log walls Wilder comes in with Corbett and locks him in the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind if I get some stuff from my kit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder does mind.  He locks the duffel bag and Corbett's in his desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sam, listen -- I shot to defend my man.  Other guy drew first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that was all, fine.  But carving him up, stranding the others, that's too fucking much. Is everything that walks, crawls, flies or swims fair game to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) I'll get loose before that plane comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try me.  I'll kill you if it comes to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Eric walks into Kenai's general store, Neff hurries ov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Desmond! (grins; sticks his hand out) Arthur Neff.  Area rep for the Federal Assistance Plan.  Tell the boys in DC to keep those goodies coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snowplow, generator, TV dish... hell, we get the goddamn Playboy Channel!  Here, this is for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Eric a piece of styrofoam shaped like a commode seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Warm to forty below.  Remember, anything you want, you ask Arthur Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm has passed.   A faint CHUGGING emanates from th small orange generator trailer behind the Turtle.  Eric pulls up and parks the Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nylon storage netting along the ceiling holds Eric's research equipment and Anne Marie's photographic supplies In one corner of the Turtle are several of her black and white prints.  All are of man-made objects whose presence juxtaposed with the natural surroundings. Relieved he's home in one piece, Anne Marie meets Eric at the door and kisses him.  Carrying a brown-paper-wrapped package, Eric follows her into the kitchen, where she's preparing dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you catch Corbett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure did.  He was one of the trappers we rousted from the Haul Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there any trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was sitting in a hot tub with a hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going after killers isn't the same as chasing poachers, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) Can't help myself.  Corbett's type always pisses me off. (hands her the package) Oh, I found this at the post office.  Had your name on it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Perplexed, she looks at the return address -- Bloomingdale's.  Delighted, she tears it open.  Inside is pretty, elegant dress.  Anne Marie kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sweetheart.  It's beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were looking at it in the catalog.  Don't know where you can wear it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wear it for you.  And I can wear it when we go home.  We won't be here forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) You make it sound like a prison sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's exactly what you meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, why get into this again. As long as it's working, let's leave it alone.  It's been nice so far.  We're together --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Permanently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Do I want to be with you permanently?  Yes, I think I do. But be with what you do and the way you live?  That I don't know. C'mon, Eric, until I met you, coming back to Alaska was totally out of the question for me.  But I'm here.  I'm getting great pictures, and I'm having fun. (slips her arms around him) I love you. (kisses him) So shut up and let's eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old primer-grey station wagon rattles into town and parks.  With an unlit cheroot stuck in his mouth, "VIKING BOB CORBETT gets out and stretches.  He's 38, six-foot-si with sandy hair, beard, ruddy skin, and his brother's dar eyes. He looks around for some sign of life.  He spots Neff tending one of the windmills and walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for some trappers. Ben Corbett, Mitchell, LeMalle. Seen 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday.  Said they were going to Cache.  They were thirsty, but we were voted dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Viking Bob walks back to his station wagon, he notices Kenai poking around in front of Wilder's cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illuminated by a bare bulb is Wilder's typical bush-count front yard.  Piled are five cords of wood, boxes, tarps, stove parts, saw horses, 55-gallon drums, dismantled snow machines, wash tubs, tires, etc. Bunching his collar around his neck, Kenai shivers and so through Corbett's traps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob ambles over to Kenai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna make an offer.  Man who owns them won't need them where he's going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder peers out the window and sees Viking Bob, then tur to Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back against the bars.  Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder handcuffs Corbett's hands to the cell door bars, t quickly wraps a piece of duct tape across Corbett's face, covering his mouth. Stuffing a .357 magnum in his belt, Wilder, coatless, sli outside. As soon as he's out the door, Corbett cranes his neck and painfully tries to pry the tape off his face with the cor of the door hinge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look on Wilder's face tells Kenai to shut up.  Viking Bob realizes something's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother and the boys left me some traps to sell for them. They're gone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- To Cache.  So I heard.  Ben never said nothing to me about selling his gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett gets the tape partially off his mouth.  He pries of his boots off and kicks it through a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob!  They got me on a murder charge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder pulls his .357 out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Bob.  I'll have to keep you here 'til I ship him south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob responds by flinging a heavy trap at Wilder, t punching him in the gut.  Wilder sprawls among the junk, dropping his revolver.  Kenai freezes, not about to take sides. Before Viking Bob can come at him again, Wilder grabs for his .357. Viking Bob jumps back and bolts for his car.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He dives into his station wagon and starts it up.  As he drives past, Wilder POPS off a few rounds, but Viking Bob keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenai helps Wilder up.  Pissed, Wilder shoves him against the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You stupid, greedy, loudmouth sonofabitch!  He'll have the others here in a few hours.  You fucked me up, now you're gonna help me move him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head) Forget it, Sam.  I never work for free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie sits on the floor, editing one of her VIDEOTAP On the monitor, it SHOWS footage of the traps under the pipeline piling.  Eric comes out of the back module holdi two ELT pendants.  He glances over at the monitor and nod approvingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still can't believe I'm being financed by an oil company. Especially when they get a look at these pictures.  Technology in the wilderness; not too pretty. (re ELTs) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I should check our emergency transmitters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric activates the ELT's.  They emit an SOS pattern of ra waves -- three short, three long and three short.  This i visible as rhythmic INTERFERENCE on Anne Marie's video MONITOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Avalanche season is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winter.  Two straight months of night -- we may never get out of bed. (kisses him) Which would suit me fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prolonged darkness makes people crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me.  I'm equipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns on a small S-VHS video camera and snaps off the room lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Allow me to give you a practical demonstration of low-light infrared photography...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does so by seductively undressing for the camera.  Sh SEEN on the MONITOR, illuminated by the "light" from the stove.  Eric appreciates the show.  He crawls toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) High-tech in the wilderness. Gets me excited, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughing, he wrestles her to the rug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a full moon and a clear night sky.  Viking Bob's station wagon is parked out of sight.  He sits inside, waiting. He hears an ENGINE starting in the distance.  Sitting up, grabs some binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder's extended cab truck pulls out, heading west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bright moonlight, two people are seen in Wilder's truck as it speeds along a dirt road. Viking Bob follows at a discreet distance, headlights off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob turns and takes the literal high road -- a nar trail above the roadway that Wilder's truck is on. He zooms ahead and gets in front of his quarry, then drop back down onto the road and waits in ambush. As Wilder's truck approaches, Viking Bob turns on his bri lights and crouches behind his car door with a shotgun. Wilder's truck screeches to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenai gets out with his hands up. Viking Bob slowly approaches Wilder's truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.  Viking Bob looks in the cab.  Kenai's passeng is Dixie, the Inupiat hooker.  Viking Bob grabs Kenai and pushes the barrel of the shotgun hard against his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Where's Ben Corbett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no argument with you, Bob. Wilder said I could keep his truck if I drove it ten miles away from town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did they go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't say, but I would guess the opposite way from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob shoves Kenai against the truck, then punches h for good measure.  Cussing, he runs back to his station wagon and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Anne Marie are asleep.  Eric starts awake at the sound of a high-pitched vehicle HORN and an approaching ENGINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric pulls the door open.  Wilder is untying Corbett from the snowmobile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an emergency on my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett smiles at Eric as he walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric, Wilder and Corbett sit in the front module.  Anne Marie, nervous, wearing a down robe, serves coffee.  She stares at Corbett, trying to reconcile his quiet demeanor with what she saw that afternoon.  Corbett smiles at Eric

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eric) ...You give us a ride in the Cessna you got hangared at the pumping station, we'll be in Fairbanks in a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we should've done in the first place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could've sat tight for the transport, 'til Bob came poking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Wilder; re Anne Marie) A lot to ask, dragging him away from such a good-looking girl --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) -- To take you to jail?  It'll be my pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eric) You better get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea.  Flying over mountains can give you some nasty surprises.  Go too low, one of the clouds might have a big rock inside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard) I'll get you there all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric takes Anne Marie to the rear module, leaving Wilder with his prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bottle of Eric's Scotch sits almost empty on the table beside Wilder.  Wilder dozes in a chair facing Corbett. Corbett is awake.  He contorts his body to bring his handcuff chain under his feet and get his hands in front him.  He eyes Wilder's .357.  It's in a lefty Sam Browne holster.  No way to take it without waking Wilder. Corbett stands and inches toward the door.  As he pulls i open, the insulation makes enough NOISE to stir Wilder. Wilder gets up and pushes Corbett back into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit, I don't need this aggravation.  I'll shoot you, Ben.  Bank on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hurt you, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not too old to knock the snot out of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder's mind clears enough to realize that Corbett's han are in front of him.  He reaches for his .357.  Corbett butts into Wilder's midsection with his head.  Amazingly, Wilder stays on his feet. Corbett hurries back to the door.  Wilder lunges, bull-determined to hold onto him.  Corbett smashes Wilder across the face with his clenched hands.  Wilder goes dow hard, hitting his head on the table, and stays there. Corbett instinctively kneels to see if Wilder is still breathing.  But then, hearing MOVEMENT in the rear module Corbett flees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is pulling on his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric rushes in.  The outside door is open and Wilder lies the floor.   His holster is empty.  Anne Marie comes in a crosses to Wilder. Eric pulls a floor trap door open and digs through the company-issue equipment, coming up with a huge Remington bolt-action bear rifle.  Unfamiliar with weapons, Eric te open a box of shells and fumbles to load the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett is trying to start Eric's Scout. Eric fires a loud warning SHOT from the Turtle doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to try that handgun against this rifle, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett sits in the Scout for a long moment, weighing his odds.  He takes his hands off the steering wheel... Eric SHOOTS again, this time SMASHING the side-view mirro and window next to Corbett's head. Still handcuffed, Corbett gets out of the Scout.  Holding the .357 gingerly by the butt, he puts it on the hood of Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some day you might have to face me without a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric leads Corbett in.  Anne Marie is cradling Wilder's head. She's crying.  Eric looks at Wilder.  There is bloo coming from his ear and he's fading fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) Fetch him back? (Eric nods) Don't let him walk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric nods again.  Wilder holds his gaze on Eric, then sim stops breathing.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eric is stunned.  Quietly, Corbett sits down.  Clutching rifle, Eric sits on the floor and glares at Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Does he have people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) A daughter in Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him down to her.  There's money in my duffel bag, back at his cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett's benign attitude is chilling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better call in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the shortwave radio on.  It SPARKS and burns out The remainder of the liquor has been poured inside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thought of everything, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surviving is what I know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Killing is what you know. (to Anne Marie) Pack some food while I prep for the flight. (off her look) I'm sure not gonna let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Covering Corbett with the rifle, Eric handcuffs him to th sturdy metal bracket of a wall unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob approaches in his station wagon on a narrow di road.  The huge night sky all but smothers the weak light from the town up ahead. Cache seems a mistake -- a jumble of unpainted buildings the middle of a big nothing, twenty miles north of the Arctic Circle.  Still, it's more animated than Devil's Cauldron.  There are a hundred permanent residents, sever taverns and a three-store, fly-in shopping center.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Even though it's the middle of the night, people roam the streets, drinking and socializing.  With only a couple fe of snow on the ground, this is still summertime.  Under storefront awnings, drunken INDIANS sleep on the concrete Viking Bob cruises the main drag, looking for the other trappers.  He spots their jeep in front of a dangerous-looking saloon called the "Bear Sign Inn."

dialogues.speaker: VIKING BOB
dialogues.text: as he parks and gets out of his station wagon.  He hears familiar VOICE around the side of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, girl, talk to me, negotiate with me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk, LeMalle stands in an alley with a bored, acne-scar Oriental PROSTITUTE.  He weaves and leers, his hand stuck inside her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle.  We got a problem. Where's Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn!  Viking Bob!  Mitchell's inside, boring bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grumbling, Viking Bob separates LeMalle from the Prostitu and drags him by the collar out of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meyerling's campaign posters cover the walls.  Many have been pulled down and muddied underfoot by the drunken cro In a booth covered with grafitti, Mitchell squints and wo on his scrimshaw.  LeMalle, somewhat sober, eats a plate muktuk -- whale blubber.  Viking Bob pours him more coffe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Viking Bob) ...Ben never sent a signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta never got a chance to -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIKING BOB (Cont'd) activate.  Wilder's aiming to take him to Fairbanks, we can count on that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning he'll need a plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closest planes for hire are here in Cache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on... (to LeMalle) Remember that Cessna we saw at the pumping station on the Haul Road?  Belongs to the guy they got patrolling the pipeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you go.  Wilder's always chummy with the fuckin' Bambi-lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisps of light cut across the cold blue sky. Eric comes out of the Turtle, leaving the front door ajar He throws a knapsack of supplies into the back of the Sco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett's right hand is still handcuffed to the wall unit Terrified about being alone with Corbett, Anne Marie cautiously puts a cup of coffee in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been up north?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be.  Too keen a sense of this place in your pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months this time.  I was born in the Aleutians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your people Alaskan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie doesn't want to talk to a killer, but Corbett so soft-spoken and charming that she answers despite herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad was a Navy doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knew you had no native blood, even with your dark hair.  Blue eyes give you away.  My wife had blue eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had some good years.  Met her in '66.  She showed up one day in Coldfoot.  No one knew her.  One Sunday morning, she marched into a bar and announced she was available as a wife to the highest bidder.  Didn't work out in three months, she'd return the money and leave, no hard feelings. (off Anne Marie's amazed look) My bid was eight thousand dollars.  Beautiful girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gone, in September, laying traplines.  She went to our cache for some meat.  Got mauled by a bear.  Tore open her skull. -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CORBETT (Cont'd) Might've lived if she got help, but the exposed part of her brain froze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie shudders.  Smiling good-naturedly, Corbett loo around, spotting the package Anne Marie's new dress came

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What about you -- why come back? Classy girl like you seems more suited to the finer things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I left, moved to Washington.  When I met Eric I was doing day shoots -- products and fashion, mostly.  Pretty dull.  Eric was teaching college, and then he got the job with Northland Oil.  We wanted to stay together, so we talked them into funding some wilderness photography... and here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she's talking, the Turtle ROCKS slightly.  She looks o the tiny window.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: Eric is putting Wilder's body inside an enclosed storage compartment built flush into the side of the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Horrified, Anne Marie turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't my intention to hurt Wilder.  I'm telling you the truth.  I liked the man.  I only meant to get loose... to survive. Your cheechako boyfriend better understand that. (beat) Listen, I've got some money put away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Don't ever think you can buy Eric off, Mr. Corbett --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Cheechako?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric comes in, none too thrilled about Anne Marie chattin with Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (translating) Outsider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carefully stuffs Wilder's magnum in his belt and ignor Anne Marie's disparaging look as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Corbett) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie leads Eric out of earshot from Corbett.  Eric keeps a cautious eye on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should drive him into Devil's Cauldron, let them decide what to do with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reassuringly) Fairbanks is a three-hour flight. I'll be back by dinnertime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Realizing he's determined, she sighs and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Be careful, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK - DAWN Eric and Corbett drive toward the deserted pumping statio They cross over a prefabricated steel portal bridge spann a fast-running creek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind whips through the shot-out wing window.  Corbett handcuffs are lashed to the seat frame with sturdy nylon rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pumping station consists of three corrugated steel buildings.  The largest is an airplane hangar. Just beyond the hangar is a narrow blacktop landing strip running parallel to the Haul Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric pulls up to the hangar.  Suddenly, LeMalle steps out from behind the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle recognizes the International Scout.  He swings hi rifle up to stop it. Eric slams it in reverse and SCREECHES back around the hangar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aim for the tires!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle FIRES as the Scout rounds the corner.  He hits a fender, doing no damage.  Angry, he runs after the vehicl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric slams on the brakes and turns the Scout around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out and keep going.  They catch us, they'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric doesn't need any convincing of that.  He tears out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell runs out in front of them and BLASTS the front o the Scout with his .45 Peacemaker.  Steam HISSES out of t radiator.  Eric floors it and races past Mitchell, almost hitting him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mitchell and LeMalle SHOOT at the retreating vehicle.  On of the Scout's back tires gets blown out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric slows, shifts into four-wheel drive and continues, driving on the rim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chewing an unlit cheroot, Viking Bob pulls up next to Mitchell and LeMalle in the trappers' jeep.  They pile in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric backtracks as fast as possible in the crippled vehic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Scout heads for the Feldspar Creek bridge, it disappears from sight over a hill. 71   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK Viking Bob zooms over Feldspar Creek.  They come over the rise, but the Scout still can't be seen ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Scout sits idling in a depression near the creek bed, below the Haul Road.  Above, the trappers speed past with noticing. After giving the trappers time to get around the next ben Eric drives the Scout up the embankment and crosses back over the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric stops the vehicle.  He grabs a five-gallon gas can a a piece of cloth from the back. 73   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK The prefab bridge is the transportable type used by the A Corps of Engineers, left over from the building of the pipeline.  Eric stuffs the gas can between the abutment a the honeycombed underside of the bridge.  He puts the rag inside the spout of the can, lights it with a match and r like hell back to the Scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers realize their quarry is missing.  Viking Bob slams on the brakes and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll still catch us.  All you're doing is pissing them off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 76   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK The gasoline can EXPLODES, tearing the bridge couplings a from the concrete abutment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers see the explosion behind them.  They turn around and head toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric parks the Scout sideways to block the way to the airstrip. With the magnum at the ready, Eric cuts Corbett's handcuf loose from the seat and hurries him toward the hangar. The leeward side of the structure is a huge metal door on rollers.  Eric unlocks it and rolls it back.  Inside is a Cessna 182, dusted with snow and ice blown through the cracks by crosswinds.  Eric brushes the windshield with h sleeve. 79   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK The trappers pull up and find the far side of the bridge burning and disconnected from the creek bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric helps Corbett into the cockpit, then secures his handcuffs to the frame of the seat with more nylon rope. 81   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK Viking Bob assesses the damage to the bridge.  Loose from the abutments, it wobbles like a diving board.  Below, th water is too deep and fast-moving to be traversable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric tries to turn the ENGINE over.  The starter is slugg from cold and lack of use. 83   EXT.  HAUL ROAD & FELDSPAR CREEK Viking Bob looks at the others, bursting with frustration He climbs into the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in.  We can jump it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hop in.  He SCREECHES backwards to get a running sta REVS the engine, pops the clutch, and tears toward the bridge. As they reach the midpoint of the bridge it begins to buc under them.  With a sickening WRENCHING, the crossbar supports crumple. The jeep flies through the still-burning gasoline, become airborne, and SCRAPES to a rude stop on the edge of the pavement on the other side, the back wheels dangling in space. LeMalle and Mitchell gingerly get out and push the ass en of the jeep onto solid earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric finally STARTS the plane and taxis out onto the land strip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers drive up to where the Scout blocks their pat They pile out of their jeep and run toward the landing strip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It picks up speed and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below, the trappers watch the plane zoom over their heads LeMalle points his carbine at it, but Viking Bob pushes t rifle down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett scowls as he sees the trappers helpless below him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob watches, wide-eyed with fury.  Mitchell spits. LeMalle punches the wall.  Then he turns and repeatedly BLASTS the Scout, parked nearby, with his carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric's knapsack, an emergency kit and several five-gallon cans of aviation fuel are tucked behind the seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell were they smart enough to find us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart?  Sure.  That's why I'm sitting in this plane and they're down there blowing me kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric retracts the landing gear and banks toward the southwest.  Corbett notices that Eric seems a little unsu of the controls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Been driving long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed a pilot's license to take the job here, so I got one in six weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes the flight more interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric ignores the jibe.  He stays at 2,000 feet, making th landscape all the more immediate. Corbett stares out the window and broods.  He spots an op snow-covered area where some dark blotches mar the whiteness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) See the blood?  Pack of wolves took down a moose.  Greedy, gut-ripping sons of bitches.  I'd kill the last wolf on earth, right in front of the President of the U.S.  Stinking, cowardly predator, the wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like professional jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunting and trapping was a damn fine life. (beat) Me and Mitchell, Bob and LeMalle, we were teams.  I'd always go with Mitchell.  Good man, Mitchell.  I'd let Bob worry about goddamn LeMalle.  We'd hire a plane in October.  On the way to a dirt airstrip somewhere, we'd drop supplies.  We'd land, tell the pilot to come back for us a few days before Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While talking in an even tone, Corbett intently studies t instrument panel and scans the landscape below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea was to get to the supplies before the bears did. Along the route we'd set our traps.  Made our year's living in three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett spots a flat plateau farther in the mountains, ab the tree line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Lot of times we didn't even have a landing strip.  We'd set down on a plateau, like that one there.  Yeah, that one's easy; you could glide right in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, he turns in the seat and pins Eric against the door with his left foot. The plane flies erratically.  With his right foot, Corbet kicks the fuel jettison lever on the instrument panel, jamming it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lever, used to empty the fuel tanks in case of emergency, does so with great expediency.  All the gas is instantly discharged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett releases Eric and calmly sits back up in his seat Eric rubs his neck, incredulous.  Corbett's move was too fast and too outrageous.  In a moment, the engine SPUTTER to a stop.  Eric struggles to hold the stick steady and glide the plane down to the plateau Corbett pointed out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you got your money's worth on those lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an even chance of hitting a mountain instead of t plateau.  Eric pushes the Cessna's nose down.  The platea comes up fast. The plane drops lower and lower, pitching and yawing in t wind. It CRASH LANDS, its metal underbelly SCREECHING as it hit the jagged granite under the snow.  It stops suddenly, flipping tail over nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It rests upside down in the snow.  The men are dazed. Behind Eric, one of the extra fuel cans, now hanging upsi down, leaks gas.  In front of him, the engine is ON FIRE. Eric undoes his seat belt and rights himself, but his leg gets caught in the tangled belt.  He pulls out a Swiss Ar knife and cuts the rope binding Corbett's handcuffs to th seat.  Corbett pushes the passenger door open.  Panicking Eric tries to pull loose of his seat belt, painfully wrenching his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett rolls out into the snow.  With no time to grab hi supplies, Eric clambers from the wreckage.  He and Corbet crawl/roll down the incline of the plateau, away from the plane. A moment later the leaking gas reaches the burning engine and the Cessna EXPLODES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric tries to stand.  He cries out and falls into the powdery snow, clutching at his ankle.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Corbett realizes Eric is at a disadvantage.  But before h can bolt, Eric grabs for the .357 magnum under his coat. lies on the snow, gasping, pointing the gun at Corbett's midsection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay put!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the belly to look me in the eye and pull the trigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric cocks the gun's hammer with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be no different than shooting a rabid dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men face off for a tense moment. Corbett smiles and zips up his jacket, dispelling the tension.  Letting the hammer down, Eric looks back at the burning plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Next time you want to kill yourself, don't include me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took the odds on getting down in one piece, and I made it.  Now we're in my territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With light clothing and no supplies, this is nobody's territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound like the tourists. Know-it-alls who read about survival in a magazine.  Fuck you.  You won't make it off this mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett drops his facade of conviviality.  Eric is too an to be intimidated.  He takes the scarf from around his ne and wraps his ankle with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re Eric's ankle) I'm not gonna carry you out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  You're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, take these cuffs off.  We need to work together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric holds his wristwatch up, points the hour hand at the sun, counts forward to noon, and, accordingly, makes an approximation of their direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Last time I checked the flight plan, we were forty miles northeast of Devil's Cauldron. Southwest is that way.  No sense waiting for a goddamn taxi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimacing with pain, he gets up.  Clutching the magnum, h shoves Corbett in front of him and starts walking.  Corbe frowns -- it's tough to trudge through the snow with his arms cuffed tightly behind his back. Eric looks around and tries not to let his emotions regis on his face.  They wouldn't be farther from the rest of humanity on another planet.  Smelling fear on Eric, Corbe enjoys the view.  And waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Endicott range is full of jagged peaks, icy streams a gnarled tundra valleys.  Squinting in the glare of the sn Eric and Corbett trek through the grandiose Gates of the Arctic area.  The smoldering plane wreckage is a hard-won snow-covered mile behind them.
