Intricate patterns of fragmented rock, strips of scruffy tundra and bedrock outcrops produce lonely, foreboding mosaics upon the landscape.  The air is still.  The silen is itself a disconcerting presence.  Ten miles ahead and thousand feet lower, the forest begins.  But here, on the rock face of the mountains, Eric and Corbett might as wel be in a desert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be interesting, trying to build a fire without any wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the environment, Mr. Ecology.  Out here, one mistake is all you get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Determined and dour, Eric pushes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Why in hell you care enough about me to die taking me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't plan on dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all academic.  The sheer magnitude of the surroundin makes them feel they're the only people in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun drops behind the mountains.  A wind whips up, chilling the men through their clothing.  Eric tries not shiver.  He spies a small rock formation with a granite elbow protruding from it, making an enclosed triangle of solid rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll stop here, dig out a snow shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow shelter.  Okay.  You dig. I'll have a little sit-down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett sits on his haunches and smiles while Eric digs n the rocks.  Although he knows Corbett is testing his ever move, Eric refuses to let his patronizing air get to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Even in the drifts, this snow's too powdery to make a shelter. When you're done jerking around, reach down the back of my coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric approaches him suspiciously.  He puts his hand down through Corbett's collar.  Something is stowed inside a homemade flap in the lining of his coat.  Eric pulls out

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: folded nylon tarp with twine threaded through corner eyeholes.  He shakes the eight by eight orange tarp open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Corbett have stretched the tarp out tent-style n to the granite rock formation, making a minimal but functional refuge from the cold night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men huddle inside the tarp.  Eric keeps a wary eye on Corbett -- at all times he treats him like a rattlesnake. Eric unwraps his ankle and rubs it.  It's swollen to the size of a softball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still quite a hike to Devil's Cauldron. (beat) Days.  A long stretch to go without sleep, my friend.  You can hide behind that pistol for now, but take your eyes off me long enough to sneeze --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While poking the .357 in Corbett's ribs, Eric one-handedl unlocks Corbett's right manacle, pulls his arm through th granite elbow, then locks it back up again.  He's learnin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is hurrying along the pipeline in his business suit, following the predator's paw prints in the snow.  He peer ahead and his prey becomes visible.  But it isn't a wolf, it's Corbett.  His hands and face are covered in blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun peeks over the mountain tops, drenching them with light and color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light hits Eric's eyes.  He bolts awake from a fitful sleep.  Corbett sits, already awake, looking like he'd uproot the rock to which he's chained if he could.  He wa for an opportunity -- any opportunity -- with the patienc of a vulture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Corbett trudge up to the bank of a frozen stream bisecting their path.  It's simple -- to continue, they h to cross it.  Corbett takes in the scenery, in no particu hurry.  Frustrated, but making dead sure he's always got drop on Corbett,  Eric puts a tentative foot on the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice is too thin -- you can see the water moving underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not sitting here 'til November.  There's a cargo plane coming to Devil's Cauldron in four days, and I'm putting you on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get wet, we freeze to death in a couple hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on ice like this when I was a kid, skating.  Spread your weight, keep moving.  Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett is not about to be outdone in the guts department someone with a Master's Degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures 'you first') Be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points .357) I'm right behind you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frowning, Corbett tentatively steps onto the ice and inch across the fifteen feet to the other bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and, indeed, Eric is right behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait 'til I'm across!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric doesn't want to be too far from his prisoner.  He ke coming.  The ice GROANS and HISSES under their weight. Corbett is three feet from solid ground.  He drops to his knees, then stomach, and rolls like a log the rest of the way. Eric splays out on the ice and crabwalks across.  The ice makes an ominous CRACKING and water begins to seep throug air holes. Standing, Corbett weighs his chances of bolting from Eric Eric crawls doubletime.  He makes it onto solid ground ju as the ice under him breaks off in a big, thin, clear pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric sits on some rocks.  Corbett glares it him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most dangerous thing in the world: A regular Joe, in over his head.  You trying to prove how tough you are for me, or for yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my idea to crash the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's camp.  There's grayling under this ice. I'll snare some for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) We've got another two hours of daylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pushing it is flat wrong.  All you prove is your ignorance about breaking trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is not convinced.   Grumbling, Corbett gets up and takes the lead as they continue southward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to keep busy, Anne Marie develops some prints in t darkroom she's made from the front bathroom.  She glances her watch and sighs, her mind on Eric's overdue return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie comes out of the darkroom and hangs the prints to dry.  Outside, (OS), a car HORN blares a couple of tim Grinning, she runs to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meyerling's Dodge truck pulls up.  Anne Marie comes outsi Her smile wilts when she sees it's not Eric.  As Meyerlin climbs the embankment to the Turtle, he glances at Wilder snowmobile parked alongside the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to raise you on the shortwave for two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes past Anne Marie and goes into the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you talked to Eric?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not, but I very much want to.  What do you know about the trouble in Devil's Cauldron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you had some news --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Get this straight: I'm the District Supervisor.  Whatever you do reflects on me.  It wasn't my idea to bring you people up here, but I'm stuck with you. You are absolutely not to involve yourself in any local disputes. Whichever side you take, you alienate the other.  Mr. Corbett is quite well-known in this region.  People admire him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Corbett's a killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care if Ben Corbett makes meatloaf out of nuns and babies, he's not your concern. Understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie just glares at him.  Meyerling examines the damaged shortwave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio's on the fritz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you say Eric is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere along the pipeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that hotheaded marshal, Sam Wilder?  I heard he was in the middle of this mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam?  We haven't seen him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.  I thought maybe that was his snowmobile outside. (beat) By the way -- your truck also 'on the fritz?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blanching) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out by the pumping station, shot full of holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noting Anne Marie's distressed reaction to this news, he crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Still nothing to tell me? (no reply) Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric limps further down from the mountains.  Corbett keep pace in front of him and his magnum.  As their altitude decreases, there is ever thicker vegetation. Their tracks in the snow stretch up behind them into the distance.  The magnificence and grandeur of the surroundi cannot be overstated.  Picture the most rustic, overwhelm wilderness imaginable, and then make it ten times larger.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The men's way is once again interrupted, this time by a sheer granite drop. The steep decline would be tough to negotiate with mountaineering equipment and proper footwe Corbett peers over the edge and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to backtrack, find another way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.  It would take days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (assessing the drop) Going to be a bit of a challenge with handcuffs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric realizes he's right.  After some deliberation, Eric cautiously approaches him.  With the .357 cocked and read he undoes one of the cuffs, leaving them hanging from Corbett's wrist.  He then unthreads the nylon twine from Corbett's tarp.

dialogues.speaker: GRANITE SHEER
dialogues.text: Eric and Corbett are tied, belt to belt, with the nylon rope.  Corbett inches down first, feet spread for maximum footing, gloveless hands grasping at anything. Eric mimics Corbett's moves and follows the same path. Unable to grasp the rocks effectively, he stops and takes his gloves off.  Continuing, he winces -- the rock is col and sharp.  His hands are soon numb and bloody.  Even in dry, below-freezing air, Eric is sweating. He looks down and hangs on more tightly.  Sliding to leve ground two hundred feet below would pummel him to hamburg Corbett pauses and rests his cheek against the rocks.  Er is right above him.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Corbett's foot slips.  His right hand instinctively goes for a hold.  The dangling handcuffs sn on a protuberance, knocking him off balance. The fulcrum of Corbett's body leans out into the empty ai Eric moves down a little, braces himself and extends his leg, giving Corbett something to grab.  Corbett takes hol of Eric's shoe and tries to teeter back against the rock wall.  Adrenaline screams through Eric's system. Corbett looks up at Eric.  A careless move will send them both tumbling.  Eric clutches harder at the rocks and wai for the worst. After a long moment, Corbett regains his balance and lets of Eric's foot.  He continues his descent.  Eric lets out his breath and tries to swallow.  His mouth is as dry as granite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handcuffed again, Corbett hikes in front of Eric along th top of some foothills.  Now and again he glances behind, gauging Eric's weariness, waiting for a moment's carelessness.  Around them there is heavy vegetation now snow-covered sedge tussocks, knee-deep muskeg and twisted thickets that are treacherous and slow to tramp through. Above them, ominous clouds and sharp, cold winds are comi down from the north. But below, a mile ahead, the edge of the forest is like t hem of a great green garment stretching endlessly southwa The combination of altitude and latitude creates an amazingly sharp topographical dividing line.  Within a fe thousand yards, the landscape abruptly changes from scrub brush to thick coniferous forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get into those trees before that squall blows down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, Corbett pauses as a walloping sound ECHOES across t foothills. Just ahead, two enormous bull moose are fighting.  They r each other with six-foot-wide antlers. Corbett stares, transfixed, admiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk about ecology -- there it is.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eric turns, surprised at Corbett's unabashed awe. Catching the men's smell the moose bound away, and the sp is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob, Mitchell and LeMalle head somberly back to Cache.  They drive along a hydraulic gold mining sluice o nearby river and come into town. As the trappers park their jeep, some MINERS greet them, shouting over the ROAR of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Ben at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll want to hear about it with a drink in your mitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, a STORM rages.  LeMalle is drunk, but still able stuff himself with a thick steak.  Mitchell drums his fingers and listens to everyone talk.  With them at the b are the Miners, LOGGERS, CAT SKINNERS (bulldozer drivers) and some leathery WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Figures, Corbett getting hauled off by a Federal marshal. God almighty, how I hate the U.S. government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should pass a hat.  Send Corbett a few bucks.  We owe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's hat comes off.  It quickly gets filled with bil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Government and business.  They ruined this state. (re Meyerling poster) Like that little weasel, for instance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'People's Friend,' my lily-white -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN CAT DRIVER (Cont'd) butt.  I heard Northland got a conservation program, up along the pipeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it.  Meyerling told me that stuff's nothing but P.R. for the TV and papers down in Juneau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's full of shit.  We got run out of there by some fuckhead driving a Northland truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob hurries in and whispers something in Mitchell' ear.  Mitchell shoots LeMalle a look and gets up.  The threesome hastily exit, leaving behind the hat full of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob, Mitchell and LeMalle stand in a quiet corner near the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called the cops in Fairbanks, see when Ben is standing trial. They don't know shit about Ben or Wilder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a three-hour flight.  They shoulda got there yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they went back to Devil's Cauldron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naah, Wilder knows we got friends in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That plane might've been to throw us off the track.  Remember the bait-and-switch Wilder pulled with the Eskimo and his truck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder still woulda made Fairbanks by now.  Fuck a duck! Ben musta got loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's backtrack, try to pick up his trail.  You know the kid out on the pipeline that Wilder's buddies with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) We were just talking about him.

dialogues.speaker: EVENIN
dialogues.text: The STORM brings gusting winds and below-zero temperature Eric and Corbett move through the storm in slow motion. Both recognize the need for a truce in the face of a comm enemy.  The snow and wind cut through their clothing like razors.  They poke around for dead wood with which to mak fire.  The trees are small and healthy; little is found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts over WIND) Just gather birch.  It'll smoke like hell, but it'll burn green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awestruck by the intensity of the storm, Eric tears branc from birch trees and piles them in Corbett's handcuffed arms. They hurry back to the nylon tarp, strung between two tre trunks, FLAPPING violently in the storm.  Hunching agains the wind, Eric pulls off his gloves and reaches in his pocket for some precious matches.  His fingers are so col he can't hold them, and he drops several in the wet snow. Angry, he shoots a look at Corbett. Corbett is holding hi hands inside his coat.  He pulls them out and quickly tak the remaining matches from Eric. Crouching down, back to the wind, Corbett grasps a match between his numb fingers and awkwardly strikes it.  He ho the flame next to the kindling.  It doesn't catch fire immediately.  Corbett lets the match burn out against his fingers.  He tries another match.  This time, a flame tak hold but could succumb to the wind at any moment. On his knees and elbows, Corbett nurses along the tiny fi Eric can't control his shivering.  He gets on his knees n to Corbett and holds his coat open to further baffle the wind.  Corbett keeps his hands cupped around the flame, n

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: caring that it's burning his skin.  Finally the fire begi to grow.  Relieved, Eric and Corbett look at each other w a glimmer of a grudging mutual respect. The fire, now unattended, is smoky as Corbett predicted, burns along nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett and Eric sit under the nylon shelter.  The STORM rages outside.  Eric empties his pockets of Eskimo potato reindeer lichens, bistsort sorrel and other plants for hi dinner. Corbett has fashioned a snare from his boot laces and a t branch, and placed some crushed roots as aromatic bait ne to a small animal burrow outside the shelter.  A squirrel sticks his nose out of the burrow to investigate. Corbett sits catlike, ready to pounce.  Eric grimaces as Corbett yanks on the snare and the squirrel's SQUEALS (OS abruptly cease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett pulls his dead dinner inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your pocket knife. (Eric hesitates) I have to eat, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, Eric pulls open the small blade on his Swis Army knife and pushes it with his foot to Corbett.  Smili Corbett admires the fancy knife.  Then, BELOW FRAME, he skins and guts his catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Damn lucky this storm didn't blow down when we were on those baldheaded mountains.  It continues, we better stay put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could blow over tomorrow, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still figuring: You're either real brave or real dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Where in hell Meyerling dig you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Meyerling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  The People's Friend.  Kiss your ass with precision if there's a vote in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett eats the squirrel Eskimo-style.  Raw.  He uses th knife like a native, too, holding the meat in his teeth, then expertly cutting off a mouthful with a quick slice. Eric stares, disgusted.  Off his look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Always eat your meat raw when the weather's cold.  Does you more good, long as the entrails look clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett uses snow and the squirrel's fur to wipe the bloo from his face, then wipes the knife off and lays it, open next to his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hold onto that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a wry smile, Corbett pushes it back over to Eric. While Eric eats his dinner, Corbett listens to the STORM watches him eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure love to know where you fit in up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to do my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to fool yourself about that bullshit job, fine.  Damn shame you have to drag your girlfriend along.  You think a woman like that will be happy making moose stew for a man -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CORBETT (Cont'd) making your salary?  Look, I'll give you five grand.  Take the money and go home where you both belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fucking insult me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett smiles -- maybe he's beginning to understand Eric

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Folks come to Alaska for a real short list of reasons:  Money. Adventure.  Solitude.  Those cover most everyone.  But frontiers also draw another type of man.  One with a demon in his gut.  He comes to the edge of the world to face that demon, and lay it to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.  Sometimes they do, but usually they end up crazy or dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric ponders Corbett's words as he eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie is frantic with worry.  She has the AM/FM RADI on for company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This is "Tundra Topics" on KFAR.  Remember, as the nights get longer, be sure to stay on a regular sleep schedule.  The depression from the coming of winter that doctors call 'Seasonal Affective Disorder' -- or 'Arctic Blue' to us lay folk -- is preventable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie tunes the radio to "Pipeline of the North" on KIAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...John Byers was hospitalized in Fairbanks today for an infection in an abscessed tooth.  Mr. Byers had a toothache and attempted to remove the tooth himself with a pair of pliers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, a BUMP rocks the Turtle.  Someone is outside. Startled, Anne Marie turns the lights off and looks out t window. No sign of a vehicle or a person.  As she pulls on her parka, she glances at the big rifle leaning against the wall, but doesn't touch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her visitor, whoever it is, is behind the Turtle.  Anne Marie cautiously rounds the corner and stops dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foraging GRIZZLY sniffs around, attracted by the smell fresh carrion -- Wilder.  Eight feet tall and eleven-hund pounds, it's used to having its way.  Right now, it's hungry. With a casual swipe of its paw, its massive claws punctur the Turtle's aluminum skin, popping open the door of the utility compartment.  The bear pokes its head inside, and Wilder's body slumps out into the snow.  The bear pushes the corpse with its snout.  Salivating, it prepares to di in. Anne Marie looks around, wondering what the hell to do nE Wilder's snowmobile is a few yards behind her, parked against the side of the Turtle.  She inches toward it. Testily, the bear looks up, SNIFFING loudly. Keeping her eyes on the bear, Anne Marie feels for the snowmobile ignition keys.  They're not there.  She feels around inside the saddlebags and finds three emergency ro flares. Anne Marie IGNITES the flares.  They illuminate the area with an eerie reddish glow.  She YELLS at the bear, wield the flares like Excalibur and moves forward. The bear, reluctant to leave so hearty a pre-hibernation meal, GROWLS and cocks its head back and forth to assess threat.  As Anne Marie inches ahead, the bear stands on h legs to its full height to meet the challenge.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anne Marie tosses a flare toward the bear.  It grunts whe the flare hits it, and shuffles backwards.  Anne Marie throws another flare.  With a ROAR from hell, the bear charges.  Anne Marie falls back.  Still holding the last flare, she's forced into a crawl space under the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: UNDER THE TURTLE
dialogues.text: Anne Marie tries to squeeze out the other side, but she's pinned in by the unevenness of the hard ground.  The bear swipes at her, its huge paw inches away.  Anne Marie jabs the paw with the flare, but that only makes the bear more quarrelsome. She twists around, looking for a defense.  Above her is t cabling from the generator to the circuit box for the Turtle's electrical system.  She tugs at it, but it won't budge.  The bear SNIFFS at Anne Marie with its big wet snout.  Anne Marie notices warning a sign on a control valve:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimacing, she tries to turn the valve.  After much effor it SNAPS and opens, releasing a stream of fetid sewage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bear gets a muzzle full of the stuff.  HOWLING unhappily, it backs away, GRUNTING and SNEEZING.  Greatly offended, its appetite gone, it lopes into the forest. Anne Marie squirms out from under the Turtle and, gagging from the horrible smell, pulls off her wet parka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing one of Eric's coats, Anne Marie stands in the cen of three similarly-sized trees.  A FLARE supplies the lig The big Remington rifle leans against the tree closest to her. She tosses one end of a hundred feet of nylon rope over a sturdy tree branch twenty-five feet from the ground.  The she throws the other end over an opposing branch and stretches the rope like a clothesline.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She attaches a second length of rope perpendicular to the first and throws it over a third tree branch, midway betw the other two.  She kneels and ties something BELOW FRAME the cross-length rope. Pulling mightily on the perpendicular rope, she hoists something heavy to the level of the branches.  The flare burns out, plunging the area into darkness. Anne Marie wraps the rope around the tree trunk and nervously tries to LIGHT another flare.  As she does, the forest seems closer, sinister, filled with lurking ogres. Seized with an instinctual fear, she grabs the rifle and runs back to the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm has passed, leaving a fresh covering of powdery snow in drifts like sand dunes.  Eric and Corbett trek toward Devil's Cauldron through the ever-thickening fores Corbett has made them snow goggles by cutting slits in strips of tree bark worn like sunglasses.  Eric, using a tree branch as a walking stick, still limps on his sore ankle.  For the first time, he keeps the magnum stuck in waistband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a cabin, maybe twenty miles south of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneels to adjust his ankle wrap) Too bad we're heading west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a snowmobile. Inside a day we could be on the Yukon.  I got money there.  Remember that five thousand?  Make it ten.  Be smart.  Take it and walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bristling) You don't get it, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett takes advantage of Eric's poor peripheral vision from the visor by kneeing Eric in the face.  Eric falls backwards into the snow.  Corbett takes off like a jackrabbit.  Eric spits out some blood, shakes the stars of his eyes and yanks the .357 from under his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett bounds through the snow, dodging trees and snow-covered rocks. Eric squeezes off a SHOT, and is startled by the recoil a the blast.  He scrambles to his feet and SHOOTS again. Corbett zigzags and disappears from sight over a snowbank

dialogues.speaker: FOLLOW CORBETT
dialogues.text: Corbett runs over a frozen stream, invisible under a cove of snow.  Suddenly, the ice SHATTERS under him.  Corbett immersed in frigid, waist-deep water.  He gasps from the sudden temperature drop.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: hobbles after him, CUSSING bitterly to himself.

dialogues.speaker: CORBETT
dialogues.text: crawls to solid ground.  Disoriented from the shock to hi system, he rolls over to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric appears over a snowbank. Corbett tries to run, but his frozen, waterlogged legs fe like pig iron.  Stumbling and panting, he looks for a saf place to cross the stream.  Eric easily catches up to him Corbett sits in the snow, shivering.  He looks up as Eric trots over. Eric glares at Corbett and rubs the bruise on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing personal.  Just wanted to see what you'd do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noticing Corbett's sopping legs, Eric becomes furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Have to get these wet things off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to slow us down! Keep moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside of three hours you'd be dragging my dead carcass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuming, Eric helps Corbett up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun sinks below the horizon, creating across the mountains a spectacular show of color and shadows.  The w HOWLS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric stokes a fire at the mouth of the shelter.  Corbett' pants and boots hang to dry from branches next to it.  He huddles under the tarp, covered by his coat, drowsy and listless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay awake!  You want to go hypothermic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that means freeze my balls off, no thanks. (yawns) I'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric examines him.  Corbett's skin is white and rigid, hi lips are pale blue.  He scowls at Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Told you I'm fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up three fingers) How many do you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritable) What?!  Fuck off.  Save yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't feel cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a spring day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to doze off.  The shivering he's been repressin now racks his body.  Eric sits him up, closer to the fire and puts his own parka over Corbett's shoulders.  With hi foot, Eric rolls some hot rocks bordering the fire closer

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Corbett's legs.  Eric rubs his arms and hands, but it isn enough.  Eric loathes the specter of death, even Corbett' He shakes him, trying to keep him awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, goddammit!  You've got classic hypothermia -- crankiness, fatigue, can't feel your coldness.  Worst thing you can do is fade out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett is headed someplace far away.  Sighing, Eric turn him so his back faces the fire.  He unbuttons Corbett's shirt, then unbuttons his own shirt and lies across Corbe Eric gasps -- Corbett feels like a slab of ice.  Corbett' teeth chatter.  He's completely unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) One more thing -- this doesn't mean we're going steady.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Later, Corbett rests fitfully.  It could go either way. Eric chews on some roots and pokes at the fire to keep it lively.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: It's night.  Some color has returned to Corbett's skin. Eric turns as Corbett mumbles and clutches at the front o his shirt.  His eyes open.  He tries to sit up, but he's weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my ELT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency transmitter?  All your gear is back at Wilder's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was blown up with the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.  We'd be out of here in a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?  Nobody this far north monitors that frequency until avalanche season. (beat) Besides, I'm surprised a tough guy like you uses fancy electronics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm surprised a flat-ender like you knows cold-weather remedies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read a lot of adventure stories when I was a kid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry.  Go kill me some dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An appetite.  Maybe you won't die after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hate to disappoint you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AURORA makes a dazzling display in the cold clear sky Below, the only light on the endless expanse of dark eart comes from the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashlight in hand, wearing one of Eric's coats, Anne Mar refuels the generator.  Something catches her eye --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, headlight beams jostle along the Haul Ro

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Anne Marie caps the diesel fuel can and stows it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) It's about time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries back into the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie brushes her hair and makes herself presentable

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vehicle gets closer.  It's the trappers' jeep.  It sl and parks on the Haul Road next to the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie peers out the window.  She gasps as she recognizes the jeep.  Ducking from sight below the window she grabs Eric's coat and hurries into the rear module.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell stays in the jeep.  Viking Bob and LeMalle get o and walk cautiously toward the Turtle. LeMalle stands midway between the jeep and the Turtle, cradling his carbine.  Viking Bob goes up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie remembers something she should've taken with h the rifle.  Too late.  She hears Viking Bob's FOOTSTEPS ( come up the wooden stairs outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob knocks on the front door.  He peers through th sheer curtain on the window, into the front module.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hullo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs to the others, then tries the door.  It's unlocked. Mitchell gets out of the jeep, spits and follows the othe in, his hand close to the Colt Peacemaker strapped to his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie climbs out a window in the back.  She closes i behind her just as Viking Bob pokes his head in the rear module. The trappers snoop around, noticing that the coffee pot i still warm, etc.  The emptiness is ominous.  LeMalle pick up the big Remington bear rifle.  He opens the breech to determine if it's loaded, and sniffs the barrel to see if

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: it's recently been fired.  Viking Bob notices the damaged radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody left in a big hurry. (to LeMalle) Check outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle goes outside and shines his flashlight around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back, Anne Marie drags an evergreen tree branch behind her to cover her tracks in the snow, then climbs i the utility compartment where Wilder's body was stored. A moment later, LeMalle comes around the corner.  He noti bear tracks and scat from the prior night's visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out to others) Grizzly sign.  Looks fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob and Mitchell converge with LeMalle.  They poin their flashlights around, spotting footprints and marks going off into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tense and silent, the trappers follow the marks.  A breez RUSTLES the needles of the evergreens around them.  They stop at the point the footprints end.  A rhythmic CREAKIN above them makes LeMalle shine his light upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The light REVEALS Wilder's feet swinging back and forth above their heads.  His body is suspended in the manner o trail cache.  Viking Bob lets out a startled grunt.  He a Mitchell shine their lights on Wilder's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Sam Wilder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta wanted to keep him from the bears.  If Ben killed him, he sure as hell wouldn't hang him up like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives a husky fuck?  Where's Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers look glumly at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie jams herself behind a pile of her photo equipment.  She stops as she hears the trappers' boots (O CRUNCH in the snow past her and go inside the Turtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers peel off their overcoats.  They look around the comfortable surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get me a job with an oil company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on the couch and lays his scrimshaw and engraving tools out on the coffee table.  LeMalle helps himself in well-stocked larder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we eat, torch this fuckin' thing, and move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle digs through the cupboards and comes up with a fr bottle of Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool out.  I ain't about to get blasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashlight in hand, gloriously drunk, LeMalle stumbles outside.  He crosses to the jeep to grab a box of Twinkie and, as long as he's at it, take a leak in a snowbank. Bleary-eyed, he notices the damage to the utility compartment inflicted by the bear. He walks to it, stepping over the bear scat.  He marvels the size and depth of the clawmarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big mother musta wanted something real bad in here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle tries the door, but it's jammed shut.  He tucks h flashlight under his arm and gives another tug.  This tim the door cracks open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peers through the opening and shines his flashlight in A pair of eyes stare back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle jumps back, startled, and pulls out his knife. tries the door again.  It WRENCHES open... ...He's looking at his own face in one of Anne Marie's mirrored photo reflector boards. Letting his breath out, LeMalle pokes around the equipmen in the compartment.  Ever larcenous, he pulls a few items out, examines them, and, disinterested, leaves them in th snow.  Doing so, he comes close to uncovering Anne Marie, who sits motionless and terrified in the back of the compartment. Nothing in the compartment catches LeMalle's fancy.  Leav the door hanging open, he wanders away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After he's gone, Anne Marie reaches over and closes the door.  She can hear the trappers' (OS) CONVERSATION insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know in my gut he was here. First light, we try to get scent of his trail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sighing, Anne Marie stuffs her hands inside her parka and tries to get comfortable.  It's going to be a long night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Corbett wearily trudge through the woods.  Corbe has the tarp wrapped around him for extra warmth.  As he walks, he sniffs at one of Eric's Eskimo potato roots and takes a tentative nibble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to see the natives eating roots when I was a kid in Nome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nome?  I figure you'd be a whaler, coming from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told that's what our old man was. Planned on going to sea, me and Bob, 'til I read Jack London. Started trapping when I was ten. Mailed the furs to Sears.  Eight bucks for a skunk, three for a muskrat. (off Eric's look) That was fine money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killing wildlife not good enough anymore, so you go on to bigger and better things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a knack for seeing things the way you want to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in silence.  Corbett tightens the tarp against cold air and looks at Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't judge me.  You're a joke, coming here from a fucked-up culture, telling us what to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is fucked up -- but it's not too late to keep that from happening here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (temper flaring) All you do is keep folks from working the land, living like they're meant to.  You don't understand shit!  Trappers, hunters -- we're part of the environment.  Who's protecting us? (sourly) I've seen plenty like you.  So -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CORBETT (Cont'd) full of yourselves there's no room for other people's way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about people? You live like an animal!  A savage goddamn throwback like you belongs out here, as far away from the rest of us as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real sad you don't approve of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves Eric with his handcuffed hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tell me what I should do, Professor.  You got all the answers.  I shouldn't hunt? Fine, I'll just phone up and have a salad delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Livid, Eric backs away and knocks Corbett's hands away fr him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't push me..!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowardly bastard.  I'm in handcuffs and I still scare the piss out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric smashes his fist into Corbett's face.  Corbett reels back, more surprised than hurt.  Eric moves in, furiously throwing punches.  Corbett plows his clenched fists into Eric's midsection, doubling him over.  Gasping, Eric rams his head into Corbett and they fall into the snow. Despite the handcuffs, Corbett gets a few blows in.  They wrestle fiercely, and Eric ends up on top of Corbett.  He about to throw another punch when Corbett looks up at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) First you save my ass, now you want to kill me.  Make up your goddamn mind.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Eric lowers his fist and climbs off of Corbett.  Corbett gets up and they continue on their way in sullen silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday morning.  Chimney smoke rises straight up in the still morning air and mingles with the wisps of fog hangi above the Devil's Cauldron valley. A scratchy RECORDING of a HYMN ("We Will Gather at the River") plays through a PA system, ECHOING forlornly off hills.  The PEOPLE of Devil's Cauldron walk through the n snow to the center of the settlement.  Some, older Women mostly, head for the dance hall, where the HYMN originate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Women SING along with the HYMN.  They face a shelf holding the PA, a rusty TV and record player.  And, in fr of the shelf, an unmanned pulpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Men, including Neff, split off from their mates and g into the Maqi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff joins some other Men sweating on benches in the primitive steam bath.   Kenai sits closest to the fire. thick glasses are steamed up, but he finally looks warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilder's missing church services; you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just as soon he stay gone. Fool could've got us all killed, arresting Ben Corbett here in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted, Corbett and Eric climb across the last set of foothills before the Devil's Cauldron valley.  The town comes into view below them; faintly the MUSIC carries fro below.  Corbett looks at Eric and breaks the silence:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure my boys won't be waiting for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think you're in Fairbanks. If not, they still won't find you before the plane comes tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bet on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know how true that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric sweeps the snow from between two rocks and sits down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll wait here until nightfall. No fire, no tarp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett sits next to him.  After a long moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't mean it, you being a coward.  You're a lot of things, but chickenshit isn't one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe...maybe not.  I'll tell you what scares me -- stumbling through life, like an ordinary jerk.  That's why I want to work on the front lines, where what I do means something. (beat) Soon as I got here, I realized my job was bullshit.  Oil company propaganda.  I was ready to leave, then I thought screw it, I'll outsmart them, do the work anyway. (beat) I don't know anymore.  Maybe I am fooling myself.  That's what I'm afraid of most of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I still get a knot in my gut every season, wondering how much longer I can go on.  No 'Home for Retired Trappers' that -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CORBETT (Cont'd) I ever saw.  We're like Eskimos -- get too old to be useful, we're left on the ice to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men listen to the faint MUSIC echoing through the sil foothills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; softly) My wife used to go to chapel on Sundays.  See her friends, 'cause I was away so much. (beat) Should've been home that day. She'd be getting dressed right about now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric glances over as a look of utter desolation crosses Corbett's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers file out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guess is he's loose and heading for Chukfoktulik.  He'll need supplies; that's the closest settlement without a lawman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle carries his booty with him.  Viking Bob looks at disapprovingly as he puts the big Remington rifle in the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna leave a seven- hundred-dollar Remington behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) What you gonna do with it?  Large bore's for shit on small game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in the right hands it ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To demonstrate, he rapid-fires several SHOTS from the hip taking the radio antenna off the roof of the Turtle, shattering panes of glass in an accurate succession, and blasting the door latch off the utility compartment.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Pleased, LeMalle slams back the bolt, ejecting a spent shell.  He glances curiously at the door of the utility compartment and starts toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thought that door was open last night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit fucking around.  Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle climbs into the back of the jeep.  With Viking Bo driving, they pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grinning maliciously, LeMalle hangs the Remington out the window as they retreat.  Taking careful aim, he SHOOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle's bullet hits the metal fuel tank of the generato The kerosene fumes EXPLODE, splattering BURNING KEROSENE the rear module of the Turtle. The trappers don't slow down to enjoy the show.  Viking B hurries on to more important business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as the SOUND of the jeep fades away, Anne Marie clambers out of the utility compartment.  Haggard and num with cold, she helplessly watches as the fire ravenously devours the rear module.  Shielding her face from the flames, Anne Marie reaches under the accordion cover betw the modules.  With great effort, she unbolts the coupling bracket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie STARTS the engine, SLAMS it into gear, and lurches the front module away from the burning rear modul She shuts the motor off and, trying to hold back the tear watches the rear module BURNING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bone weary, Eric and Corbett walk toward town, staying on the outskirts to avoid being seen.  They look at one anot -- this moment seemed impossible not very long ago.  No o seems to notice as they limp into Wilder's cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark.  Eric locks Corbett up in the holding cell, no noticing that Corbett seems almost pleased to be there. blocks the windows, pumps up the pressure on the white ga lantern and heads back outside again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff pries himself from his MTV to answer a KNOCK at the door.  Eric hobbles in.  Neff notes Eric's weatherbeaten condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind me saying, Mr. Desmond, you look like hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard anything from the girl staying with me, Anne Marie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a damn thing.  What's going on?  Mr. Meyerling was here, all steamed up, looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Neff, I've got Ben Corbett with me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Here?!  Where's Wilder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at my place... he, uh, broke his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Corbett's men find out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I'm putting him on the plane to Fairbanks, eleven tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jiminy Christmas. (beat) What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett ruined my two-way.  Go to my place on the Haul Road, tell Anne Marie I'm okay and to sit tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go at dawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Don't tell anyone you saw me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Eric goes, Neff closes his door and bolts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The temperature dips as the winds shifts and blows down f the north.  Another storm approaches.  The temperate days last week seem ages ago. Kenai, Neff, and other TOWNSMEN batten Devil's Cauldron d for the STORM.  Kenai is bundled up in the cold.  The men tighten guy wires on the radio tower, windmills and cache bring firewood indoors; close off unused rooms in the general store and spa.  Then Neff and Kenai split off fro the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Via a catwalk, Neff and Kenai climb up into the ceiling struts above the partitioned cubicles in the spa to caulk roof leak with pitch.  Neff is sullen from his conversati with Eric. Kenai, however, is smiling at Neff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the smirk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet I could make some money turning Ben Corbett in.  Maybe more for lettin' him loose. (off Neff's flustered look) I was up in my cache.  Saw the Northland man come talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're out of your greedy goddamn mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett coming here stinks of trouble.  We should make the best of it before it turns around and bites us in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric stirs a pot of beans on the cookstove.  Corbett watc from the cot in the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to that good-looking girl of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You broke the radio, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I'm sure she's fine.  Seemed like a clever kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett sits up as Eric hands him a plate of beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You were real resourceful out there.  Got me thinking of this perimeter man, froze all his fingers one winter.  So he hacked the tips off and sharpened the exposed bones.  Gets along better than ever.  Yeah, maybe I underestimated you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked you better frozen.  You didn't talk so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damn lucky, glimpsing this country before it's ruined, gone for good.  You saw wonders you'd only dreamed of.  That alone makes you different than the sorry bastards back where you came from, because you have dreamt them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett sees he's hit a nerve with Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Remember that demon in the gut? Sometimes it's nothing more than wondering if the so-called civilized life has bred the balls and brains out of you.  That's what you want out of this, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want want is you in jail --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A KNOCK at the door interrupts.  Eric lowers the flame on the gas lantern and peers out through a corner of the cardboard in the front window.  Frowning, he cracks the d open and slips outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Neff and Kenai.  Neff looks guiltily at Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining) He saw you and Corbett come in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dixie's waiting at the infirmary. She'll put a splint on that injured leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is skeptical of Kenai's concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let him fool you.  Real reason he's here is to buy Corbett's traps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric looks at Kenai, then at Neff.  Neff nods that it's okay.  As extra precaution, Eric handcuffs Corbett's righ wrist to the frame of the cot inside the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kenai) Okay.  You can talk to him.  But I'll keep the keys with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the wind HOWLS.  Eric enters and walks into the hallway connecting the bath partitions.  A hand grabs his arm.  Startled, he turns around. It's Dixie, wearing a threadbare flannel robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earl says you get discount. Twenty-five dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric shakes his head -- typical Kenai.  He gives her thre tens.  She smiles and leads Eric toward the "infirmary." It's actually a bath partition outfitted with an examinin table and a first-aid kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff paces nervously.  Corbett smiles at him and Kenai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically) Look, Ben, we don't want any trouble.  The kid's got the key, and besides, he looks edgy enough to use that magnum he's carrying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  I'll get loose in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any traps you don't want, I'll pay cash money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess someone should use them. Open the bottom drawer in Wilder's desk.  My kit's in there.  Might as well unload everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenai tugs on the drawer.  It's locked.  Undaunted, he jimmies it open with a knife.  Neff groans.  Kenai goes t throw Corbett the duffel bag, but Neff grabs it.  He chec for weapons, pulling out a hunting knife.  Satisfied, he hands Corbett the bag through the bars. With his free hand, Corbett digs through his belongings: clothing, freeze-dried provisions, jerky, paperback books He looks up and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric's ankle is in a resin cast.  His foot rests on a sto While waiting for the cast to set he soaks in the bathtub hot towel draped over his face.  Above him, on a wall bracket, a closed circuit TV plays a war-surplus PORNO FI The door CREAKS open and Dixie comes in.  She impassively checks his cast -- which is interesting, as she's now wearing panties, clog shoes and nothing else.  Eric takes the towel off his face and sits up, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wash your back for you.  You will like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Eric can protest, the door OPENS again.  It's Meyerling.  He snaps his fingers at Dixie to shoo her and she scurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to interrupt playtime, but why the hell are you caught up in a local matter when I gave you express instructions to the contrary?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the shit, Leo.  I might need your help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consisting of a handful of sod-roof cabins, mostly bars, Chukfoktulik is a way station in the coniferous forest, sixty miles southeast of Devil's Cauldron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the seats pushed back, LeMalle peels the town's lone WHORE out of her parka.  He's got the motor running for warmth.  Her gold tooth glints in the light from the building next to them.  The locating screen on the beat-u radio beacon receiver bolted to the dash GLOWS phosphorescent green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got nice beds upstairs, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm standin' guard duty. Besides, rather spend the room money on sloppy seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the sound of LeMalle's exertions there begins an insistent succession of BEEPS.  The Whore looks over LeMalle's shoulder at the locating device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tiger --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle turns and immediately loses interest in the Whore Pushing her off of him, he blows the jeep's HORN three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Meyerling are in the middle of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I won't let a killer walk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alleged killer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this matter to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sneering) You can't see past your lousy little assignment, sniffing around the pipeline.  The few voters there are in this district look up to Corbett, and I'm not about to alienate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should release Corbett because you want some votes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This miserable wilderness is a state of the union.  Policy's made here the same way as in the civilized world: at the ballot box.  That's the beauty of it -- these icebox cowboys are living a century too late.  Get them on your side, it's like buying Manhattan for beads.  With a handful of votes you control the greatest frontier since white men stumbled onto the New World.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some day these people'll wake up, and you'll be the first one they'll run out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric's attention turns to a rhythmic INTERFERENCE on the screen.  There are three short bursts, followed by three long bursts.  Something about it is very familiar. Scowling, he sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Shit... (to Meyerling; distracted) Do what you have to.  So will I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric climbs out of the water and pulls his pants on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenai sorts through the tangle of Corbett's traps.   The door bursts open and Eric hobbles in.  Gun drawn, Eric unlocks the cell door.  He rips Corbett's shirt open. Looking around, he sees Corbett's duffel bag sitting by t cot.  Digging through it, he finds at the bottom of the b an ELT with a small red LED flashing on it. Furious, he flings it against the wall, smashing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The green dot on the screen and rhythmic BLEEP go suddenl dead, just as Viking Bob and Mitchell run up to the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Northwest.  Devil's Cauldron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle dumps the half-naked Whore out onto the snow. Viking Bob starts the jeep and they roar off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric shoves Kenai and Neff out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay out of my face until I'm gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the door.  Corbett smiles his Cheshire smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; picks up ELT) Emergency transmitter?  What happened to signal mirrors or two-tone smoke fires?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lets us watch each other's backs over a wide area.  Only thing messed me up this time was getting arrested in the baths. ELT was in my duffel bag, not around my neck where it should've been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way they'll find you on a five-minute signal.  And no way -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ERIC (Cont'd) they'll get here in eight hours in this weather, unless they're right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't disappointed me yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat, dry snowflakes pour through the still air.  Gloomy clouds hang immediately overhead.  Visibility is ten feet the temperature is below zero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 5:30 AM.  Sitting at Wilder's desk, Eric pries the t from some bullets and dumps the gunpowder into a styrofoa cup. He rings the top of the cup with bluetip matches, th seals it with masking tape.  Watching him from the cell, Corbett smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashbomb, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric doesn't answer.  He pulls on a heavy overcoat of Wilder's.  Putting the unused bullets back in Wilder's de Eric finds Corbett's .44 magnum.  He puts it and some speedloaders full of .357 hollowpoints in his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric hobbles across town to the hot springs under cover o the early hour and heavy snowfall.  He paces out several circuitous routes from the rental cabins to the airstrip the edge of town, pausing now and again along the way. He hears a door SQUEAK open and someone COUGH nearby, so stands motionless in the snow. Bundled in wool blankets, Kenai trundles down to his outhouse. After Kenai passes by, Eric sneaks inside the spa.  He climbs up into the catwalk. As Kenai goes back to his cabin, he notices that the anti bear traps on display in front of the general store are missing.  Suddenly, Eric grabs him and pulls him into the spa doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric's unexpected appearance startles Kenai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to rent a cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem with Sam Wilder's place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you rent me a cabin, or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty clever:  If the trappers got that signal beacon and get here in time, Sam's is the first place they'll look.  They may figure you're waiting for an airplane, so you can't stay in the shack by the airstrip.  Last place they'd expect you is on the far side of town. (shakes his head) I can't afford any trouble --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes out all his cash) -- Here's a hundred dollars.  And if you or anyone else will back me up on this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs money) -- Forget it.  And try not to bleed on my throw rugs. (walks away, then turns back) Why do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have to ask, you wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, there is the high-pitched WHINE of a snowmobile (OS) driving into town.  Eric cautiously follows the SOUN

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: He listens as the vehicle cuts across town toward Neff's house.  The snowfall is too thick to see who it is.  Eric

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: moves in as close as he dares.  The ENGINE stops (OS) and FOOTSTEPS crunch up Neff's driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A person in a hooded parka stands on Neff's stoop, about knock.  Magnum drawn, Eric suddenly appears from the curt of falling snow.  He shoves the person against the side o the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Anne Marie.  She gasps.  Seeing Eric, she's more ang than relieved.  Eric puts the gun back in his waistband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric!  Why aren't you in Fairbanks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls her away from Neff's doorstep.  Her anger dissolving, she wraps her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, Christ, sweetheart.  Four days!  I thought you were dead, or worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stay here.  Go back to the Turtle.  I'll meet you back there in a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stung by his coolness) What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you everything later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Corbett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  A transport plane is due at eleven.  Once I put him on it, it's all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't one, unless Corbett's men get here before the plane does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie grasps the situation with a sickening clarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the people here handle it. It's their marshal Corbett killed!

dialogues.speaker: CUTAWAY
dialogues.text: has been eavesdropping on the conversation through his window.  The news about Wilder stuns him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Anne Marie, you being here only complicates things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric knows she won't relent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the snowmobile, park it behind Wilder's cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sighing, she STARTS the snow machine.  Most of her photo gear is lashed to the saddlebags.  As she pulls away, Eri limps back to Neff's house and knocks on the door. INT.  NEFF'S HOUSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaken, Neff opens the door and lets Eric in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just on my way to your ladyfriend's, but I guess she found you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Sorry I barked at you last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the one should be sorry... Goddamn Kenai, always out for a score.  I never should've let him go over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd sure like that favor you offered a while back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff gets a seasick look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mr. Desmond, I didn't count on it turning this ugly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastards killed Sam, you think they won't kill the rest of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be three, four men at the most.  I have some backup, nothing will happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm real sorry.  In a while, you're gone from this country. But we live here.  No one wants to mix it up with those hombres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neff opens the door for Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) You don't care enough about Sam to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Sam Wilder was my cousin. He's why I came to Alaska.  All his letters, saying what a paradise it is.  But me ending up dead won't do Sam a lick of good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie waits in front as Eric hobbles up.  She looks his bad ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing broken.  C'mon, we have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads her inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corbett is calmly reclining on the cot in the holding cel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could've told you no one would help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing Anne Marie, he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to Anne Marie) Maybe you can talk sense into your boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Anne Marie) Either way, you better clear out. I don't want anyone innocent getting harmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This comment has the intended effect on Anne Marie.  Angr Eric throws Corbett a coat.  Corbett puts it on.  Reachin through the bars, Eric cuffs Corbett's hands together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're moving.  Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they exit, Corbett's sardonic look makes Anne Marie shiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ten-by-ten cabin is furnished with two sagging cots, beat-up color TV set, a cookstove and a half-drum heat stove.  Built into the rear wall is a rustic dumb waiter that once lowered perishables into the icy waters of a now-dry stream. Eric checks his watch.  6:15 AM.  He bolts the door and blocks the windows, opening one enough to let sound in fr outside.  He extinguishes the Benman lantern and douses t fire in the heat stove so no smoke will emit from the chimney.  Anne Marie slumps into the corner next to the d waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll catch a chill by that dumb waiter shaft.  Sit on the cot. (hands her the .44) Keep this pointed at him if I get preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Anne Marie reluctantly takes the huge gun.  Trying to all her fears, Eric sits and brushes the hair from her face. Corbett intently watches them.  Before he can say anythin Eric shoots him a cold look.  Corbett stays quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pall hangs over the town.  People know to stay inside. Time crawls by. In his house, Neff, for once, has his TV turned off.  He tries to read and listens for sounds outside. In the spa, water DRIPS somewhere.  All the stalls are empty. In his sod house, Kenai looks out his one tiny window at curtain of snow.  Dixie comes up behind him and puts her hands on his shoulders.  He looks up at her, glum. In Wilder's empty cabin, his belongings are scattered abo as if expecting his imminent return. In the rental cabin, Eric checks his watch.  10:45 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a MOTOR grows in volume, then abruptly cease The trappers' jeep APPEARS in the snowfall on the road in town.  It coasts quietly in and stops behind the cover of woodpile across from Wilder's cabin. The trappers get out of the jeep.  LeMalle has Eric's Remington, Mitchell has his Peacemaker, and Viking Bob carries LeMalle's old carbine.  Mitchell spits.  It's so cold outside that the spittle freezes and CRACKS before i hits the ground. They fan out and approach Wilder's cabin.

dialogues.speaker: TRAPPERS
dialogues.text: The cabin comes more clearly into view as the trappers mo closer.  There is no sign of life.  Viking Bob gestures f the others, now positioned on either side of the cabin, t crouch down for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) Ben?  Ben Corbett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.  Carbine held at his hip, Viking Bob walks u to the door and, with a mighty kick, BREAKS it in.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WILDER'S CABIN DOOR
dialogues.text: Viking Bob points the carbine at an empty room.  He notic however, Corbett's duffel bag on the floor of the cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trappers march through town like an advancing army, looking for some sign of Corbett.  LeMalle stops to dig through his pockets for some food.  All he comes up with the stump of a candy bar.  Viking Bob looks at him impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, we pull Ben's ass out of the fire, I'll get you a whole damn crate of Snickers bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insulted) I'm right fuckin' here with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To prove his point, LeMalle trots from dwelling to dwelli looking through windows and letting himself in through an unlocked door.  This proves fruitless, so he lets out a frustrated YELL.  Pointing the Remington skyward, he lets off a couple thunderous SHOTS that ECHO back off the foothills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the shots, Eric pushes Anne Marie against the flo Cautioning her to stay put, he crawls to the window and tries to see through the snowfall.  After a moment of silence, from outside, not too far away:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben!  Speak out before I torch every dump in town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric points the magnum at Corbett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer and I'll shoot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kill me, you sign your death warrant. (re Anne Marie) And hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viking Bob and Mitchell come running over to LeMalle. LeMalle fires another couple SHOTS for emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls out) You hear me?  Ben?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to LeMalle) Ease off.  We do this my way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and the others strain their ears for a clue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; calls out) Whoever's holding Ben Corbett, listen to me: we just want to know he's okay.  He is, nobody gets hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mind racing, Eric stares at Corbett.  Despite the freezing temperature of the room, he's sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know I'm here.  I don't say something, they'll plow this town under.  You willing to accept that responsibility?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Setting his resolve, Eric drags Corbett to the window.  H pushes the barrel of the magnum against Corbett's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say you're okay.  Tell them I'll kill you if they rush us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne Marie bites her lip and tries to maintain a brave front.  Despite the gun in his face, Corbett remains calm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts through window) Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing Corbett's voice, the trappers spin around, trying ascertain its direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  I got a nervous man here with a magnum up my nose.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The trappers follow his VOICE toward the rental cabins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in one piece?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.  Look forward to seeing you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric pulls Corbett away from the window.  He shoots a loo at Anne Marie.  They're in a bind and she knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LeMalle grabs Viking Bob's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Viking Bob) Sweet-talk won't get shit. (calls out) Choose it, asswipe -- cut Corbett loose, or soon as you come outside, I put a fuckin' bullet through your eye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric glances at Corbett, whose grim look certifies LeMall boast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow's to their advantage, kid. You can't see them, but soon as that plane comes, they'll sure as hell know where we're going. Wise up.  Take me to the Yukon. I'll give you that money and guarantee you'll walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why offer a buyoff with your gunmen waiting outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The time has passed for men like them and me.  I know it.  But they're still fighting for survival, like cornered animals. That's why they'll kill you. -more-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
